original_text: In this paper, we present our experimental observations on how solvents can vary the TPA and TPF properties of fluorescent rhodamine (Rh) dyes Rh6G, RhB and Rh101. Rhodamines are well-known xanthenes dyes, which have been extensively used for many widespread applications in single-molecule detection [24], DNA-sequence determination [25], fluorescence labelling [26], etc. due to their strong fluorescence over the visible spectral region. Molecular geometries of rhodamine dyes are well-known [27,28] and indicate that all the structures are non-centrosymmetric. In general, for centrosymmetric molecules, TPA is forbidden when tuned to the transitions at one-half of the excitation frequencies. However, for non-centrosymmetric molecules due to symmetry relaxations, the single-photon absorption (SPA) peaks and TPA peaks may coincide. So we set our primary aim to find the effect of solvent polarity on the correlation of SPA and TPA peaks for all the dyes.
original_translation: En este documento, presentamos nuestras observaciones experimentales sobre cómo los solventes pueden variar las propiedades de TPA y TPF de los colorantes fluorescentes de rodamina (Rh) Rh6G, RhB y Rh101. Las rodaminas son colorantes xanteno bien conocidos, que han sido ampliamente utilizados en muchas aplicaciones comunes en la detección de moléculas individuales [24], determinación de secuencias de ADN [25], etiquetado de fluorescencia [26], etc., debido a su fuerte fluorescencia en la región espectral visible. Las geometrías moleculares de los colorantes de rodamina son bien conocidas [27,28] e indican que todas las estructuras son no centrosimétricas. En general, para moléculas centro-simétricas, la TPA está prohibida cuando se ajusta a las transiciones a la mitad de las frecuencias de excitación. Sin embargo, para moléculas no centro-simétricas debido a relajaciones de simetría, los picos de absorción de un solo fotón (SPA) y los picos de absorción de dos fotones (TPA) pueden coincidir. Así que establecimos nuestro objetivo principal de encontrar el efecto de la polaridad del solvente en la correlación de los picos de SPA y TPA para todos los tintes.
original_sentences: In this paper, we present our experimental observations on how solvents can vary the TPA and TPF properties of fluorescent rhodamine (Rh) dyes Rh6G, RhB and Rh101.

Rhodamines are well-known xanthenes dyes, which have been extensively used for many widespread applications in single-molecule detection [24], DNA-sequence determination [25], fluorescence labelling [26], etc. due to their strong fluorescence over the visible spectral region.
Molecular geometries of rhodamine dyes are well-known [27,28] and indicate that all the structures are non-centrosymmetric.
In general, for centrosymmetric molecules, TPA is forbidden when tuned to the transitions at one-half of the excitation frequencies.
However, for non-centrosymmetric molecules due to symmetry relaxations, the single-photon absorption (SPA) peaks and TPA peaks may coincide.
So we set our primary aim to find the effect of solvent polarity on the correlation of SPA and TPA peaks for all the dyes.

In this paper, we present our
experimental observations on how solvents can vary the TPA and TPF properties of fluorescent rhodamine (Rh) dyes
Rh6G, RhB and Rh101.

Rhodamines are well-known xanthenes dyes, which have been extensively used for many widespread applications in single-molecule detection [24], DNA-sequence determination [25], fluorescence labelling [26], etc. due to their strong fluorescence over the visible spectral region.
Molecular geometries of rhodamine dyes are well-known [27,28] and indicate that all the structures are non-centrosymmetric.
In general, for centrosymmetric molecules, TPA is forbidden when tuned to the transitions at one-half of the excitation frequencies.
However, for non-centrosymmetric molecules due to symmetry relaxations, the single-photon absorption (SPA) peaks and TPA peaks may coincide.
So we set our primary aim to find the effect of solvent polarity on the correlation of SPA and TPA peaks for all the dyes.

original_annotated_sentences:
In this paper, we present our experimental observations on how solvents can vary the TPA and TPF properties of fluorescent rhodamine (
Rh
) dyes Rh6G, RhB and Rh101.

Rhodamines are well-known xanthenes dyes, which have been extensively used for many widespread applications in single-molecule detection [24], DNA-sequence determination [25], fluorescence labelling [26], etc. due to their strong fluorescence over the visible spectral region.
Molecular geometries of rhodamine dyes are well-known [27,28] and indicate that all the structures are non-centrosymmetric.
In general, for centrosymmetric molecules, TPA is forbidden when tuned to the transitions at one-half of the excitation frequencies.
However, for non-centrosymmetric molecules due to symmetry relaxations, the single-photon absorption (SPA) peaks and TPA peaks may coincide.
So we set our primary aim to find the effect of solvent polarity on the correlation of SPA and TPA peaks for all the dyes.
original_annotated_samples:
In this paper, we present our experimental observations on how solvents can vary the TPA and TPF properties of fluorescent rhodamine (
Rh
) dyes Rh6G, RhB and Rh101.
translated_annotated_samples:
Output: En este documento, presentamos nuestras observaciones experimentales sobre cómo los disolventes pueden variar las propiedades de TPA y TPF de los colorantes fluorescentes de rodamina (
Rh
) Rh6G, RhB y Rh101.
Rh.translated_text:
Output: En este documento, presentamos nuestras observaciones experimentales sobre cómo los disolventes pueden variar las propiedades de TPA y TPF de los colorantes fluorescentes de rodamina (
Rh
) Rh6G, RhB y Rh101. Las rodaminas son colorantes xanteno bien conocidos, que han sido ampliamente utilizados en muchas aplicaciones comunes en la detección de moléculas individuales [24], determinación de secuencias de ADN [25], etiquetado de fluorescencia [26], etc., debido a su fuerte fluorescencia en la región espectral visible. Las geometrías moleculares de los colorantes de rodamina son bien conocidas [27,28] e indican que todas las estructuras son no centrosimétricas. En general, para moléculas centro-simétricas, la TPA está prohibida cuando se ajusta a las transiciones a la mitad de las frecuencias de excitación. Sin embargo, para moléculas no centro-simétricas debido a relajaciones de simetría, los picos de absorción de un solo fotón (SPA) y los picos de absorción de dos fotones (TPA) pueden coincidir. Así que establecimos nuestro objetivo principal de encontrar el efecto de la polaridad del solvente en la correlación de los picos de SPA y TPA para todos los tintes.

relajaciones de simetría
, los picos de absorción de fotones individuales (SPA) y los picos de absorción de dos fotones (TPA) pueden coincidir. Así que establecimos nuestro objetivo principal de encontrar el efecto de la polaridad del solvente en la correlación de los picos de SPA y TPA para todos los tintes.

original_annotated_sentences:
In this paper, we present our experimental observations on how solvents can vary the
TPA
and TPF properties of fluorescent rhodamine (Rh) dyes Rh6G, RhB and Rh101.

Rhodamines are well-known xanthenes dyes, which have been extensively used for many widespread applications in single-molecule detection [24], DNA-sequence determination [25], fluorescence labelling [26], etc. due to their strong fluorescence over the visible spectral region.
Molecular geometries of rhodamine dyes are well-known [27,28] and indicate that all the structures are non-centrosymmetric.

In general, for centrosymmetric molecules,
TPA
is forbidden when tuned to the transitions at one-half of the excitation frequencies.

However, for non-centrosymmetric molecules due to symmetry relaxations, the single-photon absorption (SPA) peaks and
TPA
peaks may coincide.

So we set our primary aim to find the effect of solvent polarity on the correlation of SPA and
TPA
peaks for all the dyes.

para todos los tintes.
